passage_list.text:
The new land was nothing like the old land. Not a year after my grandfather arrived, the raisin went bust.

The Armenian and Japanese farmers had planted so many grapes to dry into raisins that Sun-Maid couldn’t sell half of them. Who would buy the other half became a question of such wonderful theater, tragic and comic, that even Fresno’s sage, William Saroyan, would weigh in. If we could only persuade every mother in China to put a single raisin in her pot of rice, we’d have the glut solved, he mused.

Just as the bust hit, the great drought of the 1920s hit, too, revealing the folly and greed of California agriculture. It wasn’t enough that the farmers had taken the five rivers. They were now using turbine pumps to seize the aquifer, the ancient lake beneath the valley. In a land of glut, they were planting hundreds of thousands more acres of crops. This bigger footprint wasn’t prime farmland but poor, salty dirt beyond rivers’ reach. As the drought worsened, the new farms were extracting so much water out of the ground that their pumps couldn’t reach any lower. Their crops were withering.

A cry went out from the agrarians to the politicians: “Steal us a river.” They were eyeing the flood flows of the Sacramento River up north. If the plan sounded audacious, well, just such a theft had already been accomplished by the City of Los Angeles, reaching up and over the mountain to steal the Owens River.

This is how the federal government, in the 1940s, came to build the Central Valley Project, damming the rivers and installing mammoth pumps in the Sacramento–San Joaquin Delta to move water to the dying farms in the middle. This is how the state of California, in the 1960s, built the State Water Project, installing more pumps in the delta and a 444-mile-long aqueduct to move more water to grow more farms in the middle and more houses and swimming pools in Southern California.

This is how we’ve come to the point today, during the driest decade in state history, that valley farmers haven’t diminished their footprint to meet water’s scarcity but have added a half million more acres of permanent crops—more almonds, pistachios, mandarins. They’ve lowered their pumps by hundreds of feet to chase the dwindling aquifer even as it dwindles further, sucking so many millions of acre-feet of water out of the earth that the land is sinking. This subsidence is collapsing the canals and ditches, reducing the flow of the very aqueduct that we built to create the flow itself.

How might a Native account for such madness?

No civilization had ever built a grander system to transport water. It sprawled farmland. It sprawled suburbia. It made rise three world-class cities, and an economy that would rank as the fifth largest in the world. But it did not change the essential nature of California. Drought is California. Flood is California. One year our rivers and streams produce 30 million acre-feet of water. The next year, they produce 200 million acre-feet. The average year, 72.5 million acre-feet, is a lie we tell ourselves.

I am sitting on the porch of a century-old farmhouse, eating kebabs and pilaf with David “Mas” Masumoto. We’re looking out in near silence at his eighty acres of orchards and vineyards not far from the Kings River. His small work crew has gone home. His wife, Marcy, is doing volunteer work overseas, and their three dogs, all stinking, know no bounds. The whole place looks exhausted, like a farm where the farmer has died. But Mas, nearing sixty-eight, is as alive as ever.

We got to know each other twenty-five years ago on the occasion of his first book, Epitaph for a Peach, a memoir about a farm passed down from father to son and the son’s determination not to plow under an old variety of the fruit. The heirloom was called Sun Crest, and it had fallen out of favor with the market because it bruised too easily. Golden, sweet, and juicy, it was worth saving, Mas thought. “You take one bite, and it throws you back in time,” he had told me then. “Fruit is memory.”

I hadn’t heard a farmer talk that way since my grandfather, and so I wrote a story about him in the Los Angeles Times, and he handed me a young Sun Crest to plant in my own backyard, and it bore so many peaches next to the swimming pool that my wife, after our divorce, declared the tree a “mess” and pulled it out. Mas, on the other hand, had saved the peach. Chef Alice Waters, for one, read his book and started serving Sun Crests, all by themselves, as dessert at Chez Panisse.

He points to a spot in the orchard where they’re still standing, more gnarled and weather-beaten but still producing. He counts himself among the lucky. His father, Takashi, chose this land well. It sits inside an irrigation district with an early call on the river. Even in low-runoff years, his water table gets recharged.

“We’re irrigating right now, matter of fact,” he says. “The water table has dropped some, but out here that means we’re sitting at seventy feet [deep]. Up and down the valley, it doesn’t get much better than that.”

questions.question: What is the main idea of the passage?

options.A: The raisin industry in California faced a crisis
options.B: William Saroyan solved the raisin glut

questions.explanation: The passage focuses on the crisis in the raisin industry due to overproduction, making A the correct answer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Focus on the main subject and the author's primary point when identifying central ideas.

questions.question: As used in the passage, 'folly' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: The term 'folly' is used to describe the foolishness and greed of California agriculture, making B the correct answer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use context clues to determine the meaning of descriptive words.

questions.question: Based on the passage, what can be inferred about the agrarians' request to 'steal us a river'?

options.D: They wanted to move to Los Angeles

questions.explanation: The passage suggests that the agrarians were desperate for water, as they requested the government to divert a river, making B the correct answer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use evidence from the text to support your inferences and avoid assumptions.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the passage?

options.A: To describe the history of water projects in California
options.B: To criticize the State Water Project
options.C: To argue for more dams in California
options.D: To explain the benefits of aqueducts

questions.explanation: The passage focuses on the history of water projects in California, making A the correct answer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the author's main purpose by analyzing the focus and tone of the passage.

questions.question: Which evidence supports the claim that California farmers are exacerbating water scarcity?

options.A: They have added more acres of permanent crops
options.C: They have reduced their water usage

questions.explanation: The passage states that farmers have added more acres of permanent crops despite water scarcity, making A the correct answer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for direct evidence in the text to support claims and answer choices.

questions.question: How does the passage connect California's water system to its economy?

options.A: The water system has no impact on the economy
options.B: The water system supports a large economy
options.C: The water system has caused economic decline
options.D: The water system is unrelated to agriculture

questions.explanation: The passage states that the water system supports a large economy, including agriculture and cities, making B the correct answer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Analyze how different parts of the text relate to each other to answer cross-text connection questions.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the sentence 'The whole place looks exhausted, like a farm where the farmer has died'?
questions.explanation: The sentence emphasizes the farmer's vitality despite the farm's exhausted appearance, making B the correct answer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay attention to sentences that highlight contrasts or emphasize specific points.

questions.question: What can be inferred about Masumoto's attitude toward the Sun Crest peach?

options.C: He wanted to replace it with a new variety
options.D: He was indifferent to its fate

questions.explanation: The passage suggests that Masumoto valued the Sun Crest peach for its historical and emotional significance, making B the correct answer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use specific details from the text to make accurate inferences.

questions.question: As used in the passage, 'heirloom' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: The term 'heirloom' refers to a traditional variety of fruit, making C the correct answer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use context clues to determine the meaning of technical terms.

questions.question: What is the main focus of the passage?

options.A: The challenges of farming in California
options.B: The history of the Sun Crest peach
options.D: The impact of climate change on farming

questions.explanation: The passage focuses on the benefits of irrigation districts, making C the correct answer.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the main focus by looking for repeated ideas or concepts in the passage.

scoring_guidelines.800_level_performance: Students scoring at this level demonstrate mastery of all tested skills, including advanced analysis, synthesis, and reasoning. They can accurately interpret complex texts and make nuanced inferences.
scoring_guidelines.700_level_performance: Students scoring at this level show strong comprehension and reasoning skills but may struggle with higher-level analysis and synthesis. They can identify main ideas and details but may miss subtle nuances in the text.

explanation_summary.hard_questions: Hard questions test advanced analytical and reasoning skills, often requiring students to infer meaning, analyze complex text structures, or make connections between different parts of the text.
explanation_summary.medium_questions: Medium questions assess comprehension and vocabulary in context, with a focus on understanding main ideas, details, and the author's purpose.
explanation_summary.easy_questions: Easy questions evaluate basic comprehension and the ability to identify explicit information in the text, such as main ideas and straightforward details.
